quotes: Code is poetry written in logic 🎨💻
Debugging: Being the detective in a crime you committed 🕵️‍♂️
There are only 10 types of people: those who understand binary and those who don't 😄
First, solve the problem. Then, write the code 🧠⚡
Code never lies, comments sometimes do 📝✨
A programmer's best friend is coffee and Stack Overflow ☕🔍
Talk is cheap. Show me the code. - Linus Torvalds 💬
The best error message is the one that never shows up 🚫❌
Programming isn't about what you know; it's about what you can figure out 🤔💡
Any fool can write code that a computer can understand. Good programmers write code that humans can understand 👥
The most important property of a program is whether it accomplishes the intention of its user 🎯
Simplicity is the ultimate sophistication - Leonardo da Vinci ✨
Make it work, make it right, make it fast 🏃‍♂️💨
Code is like humor. When you have to explain it, it's bad 😅
Programming is thinking, not typing 🧠⌨️
The computer was born to solve problems that did not exist before 🤖
Software is a great combination between artistry and engineering 🎨⚙️
Good code is its own best documentation 📖
Premature optimization is the root of all evil - Donald Knuth ⚡
It's not a bug – it's an undocumented feature 🐛✨
The only way to learn a new programming language is by writing programs in it 📝
Programs must be written for people to read, and only incidentally for machines to execute 👥🤖
Walking on water and developing software from a specification are easy if both are frozen ❄️
Measuring programming progress by lines of code is like measuring aircraft building progress by weight 📏
Always code as if the guy who ends up maintaining your code will be a violent psychopath who knows where you live 😱
There are two ways to write error-free programs; only the third one works 🤷‍♂️
Deleted code is debugged code 🗑️✅
The best thing about a boolean is even if you are wrong, you are only off by a bit 🔢
Programming is like sex: one mistake and you have to support it for the rest of your life 😅
If debugging is the process of removing bugs, then programming must be the process of putting them in 🐛
99 little bugs in the code, 99 little bugs. Take one down, patch it around, 117 little bugs in the code 🎵
A user interface is like a joke. If you have to explain it, it's not that good 🎭
Real programmers count from 0 🔢
There's no place like 127.0.0.1 🏠
To understand recursion, you must first understand recursion 🔄
I don't always test my code, but when I do, I do it in production 🧪
It works on my machine 🖥️✅
Roses are red, violets are blue, unexpected '{' on line 32 🌹💙
Ctrl+Z is the closest thing we have to time travel ⏰
A SQL query goes into a bar, walks up to two tables and asks: 'Can I join you?' 🍺
Why do programmers prefer dark mode? Because light attracts bugs! 🌙🐛
Programming is 10% science, 20% ingenuity, and 70% getting the ingenuity to work with the science 🔬
The trouble with programmers is that you can never tell what a programmer is doing until it's too late 🕰️
Software and cathedrals are much the same – first we build them, then we pray 🏰🙏
Hofstadter's Law: It always takes longer than you expect, even when you take into account Hofstadter's Law ⏳
The first 90% of the code accounts for the first 90% of the development time. The remaining 10% of the code accounts for the other 90% of the development time 📊
Adding manpower to a late software project makes it later - Brooks' Law 👥⏰
Good programmers use their brains, but good guidelines save us having to think out every case 🧠
The best programs are written so that computing machines can perform them quickly and so that human beings can understand them clearly 🤝
Optimism is an occupational hazard of programming: feedback is the treatment 😊
You can't have great software without a great team, and most software teams behave like dysfunctional families 👨‍👩‍👧‍👦
No matter how slick the demo is in rehearsal, when you do it in front of a live audience, the probability of a flawless presentation is inversely proportional to the number of people watching 🎭

The cheapest, fastest, and most reliable components are those that aren't there 💰
One of the best programming skills you can have is knowing when to walk away for awhile 🚶‍♂️
Perfect is the enemy of good 🎯
Code is never finished, only abandoned 🏃‍♂️
The art of programming is the skill of controlling complexity 🎨
Every great developer you know got there by solving problems they were unqualified to solve until they actually did it 💪
The most important single aspect of software development is to be clear about what you are trying to build 🏗️
Weeks of coding can save you hours of planning 📅
A good programmer is someone who always looks both ways before crossing a one-way street 👀
The only constant in the technology industry is change 🔄
Don't comment bad code—rewrite it 📝
Simplicity is prerequisite for reliability ✅
The function of good software is to make the complex appear to be simple 🎭
Programming is not about typing, it's about thinking 🤔
The best way to get a project done faster is to start sooner 🏃‍♂️
Code without tests is broken by design 🧪
A program is never less than 90% complete, and never more than 95% complete 📊
The sooner you start to code, the longer the program will take 💻
A complex system that works is invariably found to have evolved from a simple system that worked 🌱
The hardest part of design... is keeping features out 🚫
When in doubt, use brute force 💪
Debugging is twice as hard as writing the code in the first place 🐛
The best performance improvement is the transition from the nonworking state to the working state ⚡
Most software today is very much like an Egyptian pyramid with millions of bricks piled on top of each other 🏺
Software is like entropy: It is difficult to grasp, weighs nothing, and obeys the Second Law of Thermodynamics 🌪️
Computers are incredibly fast, accurate, and stupid. Human beings are incredibly slow, inaccurate, and brilliant 🧠
The good news about computers is that they do what you tell them to do. The bad news is that they do what you tell them to do 💻
To err is human, but to really foul things up you need a computer 💥
The computer does not make mistakes. What it does it does on purpose 🎯
A computer once beat me at chess, but it was no match for me at kick boxing 🥊
Computers make very fast, very accurate mistakes 💨
Hardware: The parts of a computer system that can be kicked 🦵
Software: The parts of a computer system that can't be kicked 👻
Any sufficiently advanced technology is indistinguishable from magic - Arthur C. Clarke ✨
Technology is a useful servant but a dangerous master 🤖
The real danger is not that computers will begin to think like men, but that men will begin to think like computers 🧠
Just because something doesn't do what you planned it to do doesn't mean it's useless 💡
Innovation distinguishes between a leader and a follower - Steve Jobs 🚀
The best way to predict the future is to invent it - Alan Kay 🔮
Stay hungry, stay foolish - Steve Jobs 🍎
Think different - Apple 🍎
If you are working on something that you really care about, you don't have to be pushed. The vision pulls you - Steve Jobs 👁️
The only way to do great work is to love what you do - Steve Jobs ❤️
Shaping the future, one totally bug-free commit at a time 😎✨ (hopefully)
Git commit -m 'Fixed everything' 🔧
Merge conflicts are just life's way of teaching us patience 🤝
There are only two hard things in Computer Science: cache invalidation and naming things 🏷️
In order to understand recursion, one must first understand recursion 🌀
The best debugger ever written is a good night's sleep 😴
Programming is like writing a book... except if you miss out a single comma on page 126, the whole thing makes no sense 📚
A byte walks into a bar and orders a drink. Bartender asks: 'What's wrong?' Byte replies: 'Parity error' 🍻
Why do Java developers wear glasses? Because they can't C# 👓
How many programmers does it take to change a light bulb? None, that's a hardware problem 💡
Why did the programmer quit his job? He didn't get arrays 📊
What's the object-oriented way to become wealthy? Inheritance 💰
Why do programmers always mix up Halloween and Christmas? Because Oct 31 == Dec 25 🎃🎄
A programmer is told to 'go to hell', he finds the worst part of that statement is the 'go to' 👹
Why don't programmers like nature? It has too many bugs 🐛🌿
Programming is like a puzzle, except the pieces keep changing shape 🧩
The three most dangerous things in the world: A programmer with a soldering iron, a hardware engineer with a software patch, and a user with an idea 💡
There's nothing quite like the feeling of successfully compiling code on the first try 🎉
Rubber duck debugging: Because sometimes you need to explain your code to someone who won't judge you 🦆
The best code is no code at all 🚫💻
Legacy code: Code written by someone else 👻
Documentation is like sex: when it's good, it's very good, and when it's bad, it's better than nothing 📖
The only thing worse than no documentation is wrong documentation 📝❌
Refactoring is like cleaning your room: you know you should do it, but you keep putting it off 🧹
Version control is like insurance: you don't think you need it until you really need it 🔒
The cloud is just someone else's computer ☁️💻
Microservices: Because distributed monoliths are the future 🏗️
Agile development: Because changing requirements are the only constant 🔄
DevOps: You build it, you run it, you fix it at 3 AM 🌙
Machine learning: Statistics on steroids 📊💪
Blockchain: A solution looking for a problem 🔗
Artificial Intelligence: Making computers do things that would require intelligence if done by humans 🤖🧠
Big Data: Like teenage sex - everyone talks about it, nobody really knows how to do it 📊
The Internet of Things: Because your toaster really needs to be hackable 🍞
Cybersecurity: The art of building higher walls and teaching people to jump higher 🏰
Open source: Standing on the shoulders of giants 🏔️
Proprietary software: Standing on the wallets of customers 💰
Stack Overflow: Where copy-paste programming goes to thrive 📋
GitHub: Where code goes to live, die, and be forked 🍴
Code review: The art of finding bugs in other people's code while ignoring your own 🔍
Pair programming: Two people, one keyboard, infinite arguments 👥⌨️
Technical debt: The interest rate is always higher than you think 💳
Premature optimization: The root of all evil, but also kind of fun 🌱
Spaghetti code: When your code looks like your last meal 🍝
Magic numbers: Because 42 is always the answer 🔢
Global variables: Because sharing is caring (and terrifying) 🌍
Goto statements: The programming equivalent of a plot twist 🎬
Infinite loops: The gift that keeps on giving 🎁
Null pointer exceptions: The bane of every programmer's existence 💀
Memory leaks: When your program has commitment issues 🕳️
Race conditions: When timing is everything, and everything is wrong ⏰
Deadlocks: When your threads can't agree on who goes first 🔒
Buffer overflows: When your cup runneth over, and crashes everything 🏺
SQL injection: When your database becomes too trusting 💉
Cross-site scripting: When your website becomes a playground for hackers 🎪
Denial of service: When your server decides to take a break 🛑
Man-in-the-middle attacks: When your conversation isn't as private as you think 👂
Phishing: When your email becomes a fishing expedition 🎣
Social engineering: When humans become the weakest link 🔗
Zero-day exploits: When hackers know something you don't 🕳️
Penetration testing: Legal hacking for fun and profit 🔓
Ethical hacking: When being bad is actually good 😇
White hat hackers: The good guys in black hoodies 🎩
Black hat hackers: The bad guys in... also black hoodies 🎭
Script kiddies: When copy-paste meets cybercrime 👶
APT groups: When nation-states get into programming 🏛️
Ransomware: When your files are held hostage 🔐
Cryptocurrency mining: When your computer becomes a digital gold mine ⛏️
Blockchain consensus: When everyone has to agree, but nobody trusts anyone 🤝
Smart contracts: When your contract is smarter than you are 📜
Decentralized applications: When there's no single point of failure, except everywhere 🕸️
Web3: The internet, but with more buzzwords 🌐
NFTs: When digital art meets digital scarcity 🎨
Metaverse: When reality isn't real enough 🌌
Quantum computing: When bits become qubits and everything becomes uncertain 🔬
Edge computing: When the cloud gets too far away ☁️
Serverless computing: When servers exist, but you pretend they don't 🚫🖥️
Containers: When your application needs its own little world 📦
Kubernetes: When you need a container for your containers 🚢
Docker: When 'it works on my machine' becomes 'it works in my container' 🐳
Continuous integration: When your code is always being tested 🔄
Continuous deployment: When your code goes to production before you do 🚀
Infrastructure as code: When your servers are just really long configuration files 📄
Monitoring: When you watch your application like a hawk 🦅
Logging: When your application won't stop talking 📢
Alerting: When your phone buzzes at 3 AM because something broke 📱
On-call rotation: When you're always on duty, even when you're not 📞
Incident response: When everything is on fire and you're the firefighter 🚒
Post-mortem: When you analyze what went wrong after everything is fixed 🔍
Blameless culture: When it's nobody's fault, but somebody has to fix it 🤷‍♂️
Technical writing: When you have to explain complex things simply 📝
API documentation: When you have to explain how to use your code 📚
User manuals: When you have to explain how to use your application 📖
Code comments: When you have to explain what your code does 💬
Commit messages: When you have to explain what you changed 📝
Pull requests: When you ask others to review your code 🔍
Code standards: When everyone has to write code the same way 📏
Linting: When your computer tells you your code is ugly 🧹
Formatting: When your code has to look pretty 💄
Testing: When you have to prove your code works 🧪
Unit tests: When you test the smallest parts of your code 🔬
Integration tests: When you test how parts work together 🤝
End-to-end tests: When you test the whole application 🏁
Performance tests: When you see how fast your code can go 🏃‍♂️
Load tests: When you see how much your code can handle 🏋️‍♂️
Stress tests: When you try to break your code on purpose 💥
Security tests: When you try to hack your own code 🔓
Accessibility tests: When you make sure everyone can use your code ♿
Usability tests: When you see if people can actually use your application 👥
A/B tests: When you can't decide between two options 🎯
Feature flags: When you want to turn features on and off 🚩
Blue-green deployments: When you want to deploy without downtime 🔵🟢
Canary deployments: When you test on a small group first 🐤
Rolling deployments: When you update gradually 🌊
Hotfixes: When you need to fix something right now 🔥
Emergency patches: When hotfixes aren't fast enough 🚨
Maintenance windows: When you schedule downtime 🪟
Planned obsolescence: When you design things to break 💀
Technical debt: When you borrow against your future self 💳
Code smell: When your code doesn't smell right 👃
Antipatterns: When you do the wrong thing consistently 🚫
Design patterns: When you do the right thing consistently ✅
Best practices: When you follow the rules 📋
Worst practices: When you break all the rules 💥
Cargo cult programming: When you copy code without understanding it 🚢
Not invented here syndrome: When you reinvent the wheel 🛞
Analysis paralysis: When you think too much and do too little 🤔
Bikeshedding: When you argue about trivial things 🚲
Yak shaving: When you do unrelated tasks to avoid the main task 🦬
Scope creep: When your project grows beyond recognition 📈
Feature creep: When you add too many features 🐛
Mission creep: When your purpose changes without notice 🎯
Gold plating: When you add unnecessary polish ✨
Over-engineering: When you build a rocket to go to the corner store 🚀
Under-engineering: When you build a paper airplane to go to the moon 📄
The right tool for the job: When you use the appropriate technology 🔧
When all you have is a hammer, everything looks like a nail 🔨
There's more than one way to do it - Perl motto 🐪
Explicit is better than implicit - Python Zen 🐍
Convention over configuration - Ruby on Rails 💎
Don't repeat yourself - DRY principle 🏜️
Keep it simple, stupid - KISS principle 💋
You aren't gonna need it - YAGNI principle 🚫
Separation of concerns - Single responsibility principle 📦
Composition over inheritance - Design principle 🧩
Fail fast, fail often - Agile principle 💥
Move fast and break things - Facebook motto (deprecated) 💨
